text: okay good morning everybody so what I'm
going to talk about is some research
that we've been doing in conjunction
with the African American Student Union
50th anniversary so when Dean Nathan
Oriya asked Linda Hill and I if we would
take over this project we said yes not
knowing what that would mean a
documentary library exhibit all this
stuff but one of the things that I
wanted to do as part of this particular
project is actually to use this moment
as a chance to do a little bit of
research and to better understand our
graduates and to better understand what
we can learn about the experience of
black MBA so that was really the
motivating question was what can we
learn about the career past the
satisfaction levels of our black MBAs
and this actually stemmed from some
earlier research that Nathan and I had
done a few years back for this book
called paths to power and in that book
we were trying to look at who really has
access to opportunity in the United
States does the Horatio Alger story
really ring true can anybody with pluck
and drive and determination succeed and
we looked at that from a lens of
ultimate insiders and ultimate outsiders
and one of the outsiders and so there's
a chapter about gender there's a chapter
about race there's a chapter about
socioeconomic status those were a lot of
outsider categories and what we found is
that for the outsiders that there were
four paths to power one was place and so
particularly for African Americans it
wasn't as if you could uproot yourself
and go somewhere else in the country
that was the path for some outsiders if
you had the wherewithal to actually move
to a different part of the country which
was much more hospitable to new business
opportunities you could have done that
for blacks in our database of great
business leaders it was really serving
their home community how do we actually
build a business within our environment
and so you see a lot of the businesses
centered around the black community
another ways professional networks
personal networks how they leverage
those for opportunity professional
credentials one of the things that we
found which many have you have already
found is the black leaders on our
database we're far more educated than
the white leaders in fact this sort of
path to get an additional
agree in additional credential that was
another path to success and finally
perseverance so of our database of a
thousand great business leaders that we
compiled for this historical study 40
were African American and of those 40
that were African American there were
six African American women all of them
were entrepreneurs in terms of access
and opportunity there wasn't a lot of
access an opportunity and one of the
things that we found interesting was
that there were four industries in which
African Americans were concentrated it
was finance publishing and print media
entertainment and personal and home care
products and so when Nathan came to us
about this ace 250 I thought I wonder if
our MBAs actually are mapping to this
particular path so this was sort of the
motivation of building the database has
that changed over time we looked
historically at a hundred years of
history as part of this early research
with past a power and I thought let's
actually look at our MBAs and try to
understand what we can learn about their
particular paths to power
so our research methodology was to first
build a career database I thought that
would be easy I thought are relatively
easy to get the names I
I called admissions I called our alumni
relations I said hey can you give me a
database of our black graduates and they
said no we have not captured that
information until 1990 we've captured it
from 1996 onward we have no idea so I
thought great so that was two years ago
and it's been a long process of actually
building a database of African American
graduates black graduates of HBS but we
were able to do that actually through
some of the resources that we had in
Baker library we were able to find a
number of archival data data sources to
be able to construct this particular
database and with this database we were
able to create to put in a lot of
demographic data about who they are
where they're from that sort of thing
and the other thing that we did is I
went on LinkedIn and I actually pulled
everybody's work profile and appended it
to this particular database so we can
see every position every opportunity
really to try to understand the career
path
the second phase of the project was to
analyze the responses from the black
respondents to our life and leadership
after HBS survey that was initially
conducted as part of the w50 project we
actually through Robin's effort in the
gender initiative they reach out
periodically to our alumni talk about
ask them to talk about the career
experiences and satisfaction we did a
survey in 2012 we did a survey in 2015
and we went back and analyzed that data
based on the black respondents to try to
get a sense of what we can learn about
that particular deep dive into that and
then finally we did a series of
interviews with black alumni and focus
groups about 50 different interviews
about their careers and their
trajectories and so what I'm going to
present to you is some raw data as we're
building this particular analysis so for
the data set I can now say we have two
thousand two hundred and seventy four
alumni that we know about and in the
history of HBS the first one being in
1915 which was Wendell Thomas Cunningham
that was seven years after the founding
of the school then between 1915 and 1968
there was a total of 42 black graduates
that we've been able to identify and so
part of the ASA 50 in 1968 with six
members of the class that was the
largest representation of black students
in the NBA class and that was the
formation of ASA 50 so we decided to
look at the last 40 years of history
from 1977 to 2015 and that's when we
appended all this LinkedIn data
Bloomberg biography data and we were
able to identify that there were 1821
alumni and we were able to get full
employment data for 76% of that so the
data set is about one thousand three
hundred and eighty-one that we're going
to present some information about we
have demographic data on the full 1,800
so I'll present some data which will
represent the full spectrum and then
when I talk about the career information
that's going to really be about this 76
percent so this is a chart that shows
the number of black graduates of HBS
from you can see 1969 to 2017 you see
the big spike
in from 69 to 70 the library exhibit
that you'll see later today is really
focused on these five founders of the
African American Student Union who went
to the Dean and said we need more black
students in the MBA class he said what a
lot of people said at that time and
probably still say today we don't know
where they are we can't find them and
and the students said no problem we'll
help you with that and so with funding
from the school they actually went on a
tour to historically black colleges they
actually went out to other schools as
well and lo and behold they were able to
increase the numbers but you can see
it's abdun flowed over the last 50 years
over the last about 25 years or so we've
been at a mean of about 56 in the class
in terms of the gender and country of
origin representation because I always
get that question is this just black
students from the US is it others it's
gone up to about 43 percent of the class
or women as of the 2010 Ziff I look at
the overall dataset it's 35 percent
women a 65 percent men but it's up to
about 43 percent and the country of
origin is shifting slightly where it was
upwards of 95 percent from the US by the
2010 's we've got about 10 percent
coming from Africa and a few other
percentages coming from other parts of
the globe but that gives you a little
bit of background information of who
they are and then where they went to
school so we're interested to try to
understand where our graduates came from
in terms of their undergraduate
institutions the blue bar is the total
the orange are female and the gray are
male so you can see the different
representations across the different
schools where there's a big
concentration in either Ivy League
institutions historically black colleges
or top 100 University so not a major
level of diversity in terms of who
actually get submitted that's not
surprising and I can share a little bit
about a comparison analysis that we've
done if you're interested in who are the
top feeder colleges so Harvard
I guess we like our own so is the top
feeder college over the last this is
over the last 40 years 50 years cuz this
data is from 69 to 2015 and you can see
a couple of historically black colleges
Howard Morehouse on that particular list
coming in 11 would have been Spelman if
you were interested in where that is in
terms of the representation over the
decades this is where we actually see a
concentration of Admissions coming from
more elite institution so you're seeing
black students getting admitted to
Harvard Business School coming from over
time more from Ivy League institutions
there's been an ebb and flow about
historically black colleges that's sort
of down a little bit now and then a big
bump in the top 100 and you can see
that's consolidating to where about 83
to 84 percent of our graduates black
graduates in the last decade have come
from these three types of institutions
where you saw historically this green
bar is represents other public
universities that's actually gone down
and this blue is the other private that
has gone down so more of an elite type
of pedigree to actually be admitted into
HBS which is one of the things that we
actually found in past to power was
really who where is the opportunity and
if it's coming from education who's
actually getting admitted and is that
the new funnel in terms of opportunity
and access and you can see it sort of
playing out here at Harvard I've this
with a couple of quotes from some of the
interviews and so this is one of our one
of the women that we interviewed and she
says you look around at the education of
black folks versus white folks you start
to notice a pattern but all the black
folks have superbly educated the black
folks went to Ivy League schools the
white folks went to possibly wherever
they wanted to go and you see that the
black Scouts black folks are screened
much more and she was actually talking
not about HBS per se she was talking
about on the job when she was and her
job she was looking at her co-workers
she's looking at her peers she's saying
why is it the case that all of the black
individuals I'm working with are coming
from these institutions
and there seems to be much more freedom
and access to opportunity for whites
from other areas in terms of majors
we're curious because doing the research
and I was entering this I'm kind of a
control freak so I actually entered most
the datum it's a doll knows that we
teach together I I'm a no so in entering
all of this data I kept saying all this
engineering computer science and math
and so it was curious to me to say okay
what were the majors of our graduates
you can see a high concentration
engineering computer science and math
Business Economics and then sort of
going down over time and you can see
this shift here again over the decades I
know I'm going through this quickly but
you can see the shift it's been pretty
constant although a growth in the
business degrees people coming in with
business degrees and what I wanted to do
is to do a comparison of our black
incoming students to the overall class
and we actually had comparative data for
85 95 and 2005 and 2015 and you can see
from this data that there's been a big
drop in students coming in from the
humanities Social Sciences in terms of
black students coming in and a big
increase in the Business Administration
the engineering the Natural Sciences
that's pretty consistent between so the
the spikes that I had saw thought where
they are are pretty consistent with
who's being admitted overall to the
school and now switching so it's a
little bit of a background data
switching over to some of the employment
information that we have here in terms
of functional concentrations we try to
understand what industries did our black
graduates where they concentrated in
finance about 35 percent professional
services about 18 percent that's
actually a higher concentration than the
class of as a whole so it's a bit
surprising to me that more black
graduates are going into the finance and
professional services part of that may
be that many of our black graduates a
higher proportion are sponsored by
organizations who are sending them here
and so there's a responsibility or an
obligate
if they choose to accept that particular
funding to go back to that institution
so there may be something going on with
that particular number there but that
gives you a little bit of a flavor of so
one of the things that we saw in our
earlier research was finance was the key
industry sector for the historical
leaders that we looked at it continues
to be the high highest sector here
although in the past it was really about
insurance and focused on burial
insurance and looking at opportunities
for blacks and that sort of covering the
expenses for the life here it's more
it's a broader perspective on finance
mostly on banking and private equity
hedge funds etc and then we wanted to
understand okay of the 1700 graduates we
know who are currently employed black
graduates who is the top employer and so
the top employer is self-employed and
sole proprietor so there's the numbers
are small but the thing that sort of
struck out to us that 92 of our students
our alumni are actually in a
self-employed sector and you can see the
top companies Morgan Stanley McKinsey
and Google and so was surprised to me
that Google was number four and so I
have initiated two additional
independent research project with some
students one that actually has looking
at looked at the self-employment sector
and actually interviewed the a subset of
the 92 individuals and then I have
another one that's going on now looking
at our interviewing all of our graduates
who are at Google to try to understand
what's attractive about that opportunity
why are they there what can we learn
about our graduates in that particular
sector but just a couple of thoughts on
the self-employed three hypothesis came
out from that from the the independent
project that I've been working on is it
a fact of a lack of opportunity and so
they're leaving the workforce because of
lack of opportunity is it because of
desirable to create transferable wealth
or is it to achieve some sort of a
work-life balance and in the interviews
that we have conducted so far we found
evidence for the first two not at all
for the third one in terms which is
probably not entirely surprising
but some of the students I had working
with me thought that was going to be a
big lever and they were sorely
disappointed when they saw there was no
evidence for for that one just one quote
about this individual some of these
individuals I was tired I was tired of
having bosses I was tired of what I
considered to be unfair evaluation
performance of an african-american in
the professional services industry and
professional services you are sort of
good because someone says you are good
african-americans never really fare well
in that process and there were many
quotes like that so some of them were
you know saying there's lack of
opportunity I'm not getting the shot I'm
gonna take this chance on my own to sort
of go out and what we've actually seen
in the last 50 years roughly 30 percent
of African Americans actually are self
employed or a sole proprietor at some
point in their career they actually
leave the workforce they're doing
something else they're starting a
business so it's it's sort of ebbs and
flows to be doing about 30 to 35 percent
which is slightly higher for blacks than
the class as a whole because you see our
black graduates actually opting for that
earlier than our non black graduates in
terms of current positions to actually
see where they are now we looked at
these various individuals in terms of
you know whether they were the c-suite
the upper management etc and so the
article that is in the HBR that you have
in front of you looks at one of the
things that we were interested in this
was trying to understand who are the
individuals that are in the c-suite who
has reached it and why and I'll talk a

there's a mix of representation across
the different areas where men are more
highly concentrated in the top positions
than women and this gives you a not
surprising if you sort of look at the
decade of graduation a higher
concentration in the upper management
which which you would expect okay three
minutes functional concentration the big
takeaway men are in finance women are in
marketing and strategy
and I won't spend too much time in that
in terms of mobility we were interested
in trying to understand how many
companies our graduates work for and how
long do they stay little difference
between men and women although women
tend to work for slightly more companies
and have obviously less tenure based on
the fact that they're working for more
companies and trying to understand why
is that the case and what are the
reasons for that over time and then the
last part of the presentation is really
about enabling and obstacles to success
so I wanted to present a little bit of
the data from the satisfaction survey
where we compared black respondents to

responsibility between white men and

for larger organizations than some of
the white counterparts when were
examining that as well it's hard to read

different areas professional
accomplishments ability to contribute to
society and what we found is
statistically significant differences
between our black and white graduates in
terms of opportunities to do meaningful
and satisfying work professional
accomplishments in the ability to
combine personal and career family one
of the things so I'm gonna go this very
quickly we looked at 14 different
factors that are potential enablers to

what we found is that the biggest area
of difference was certificate general
online management experience between
black graduates and white graduates in
terms of being the lack of access to
that being
not being an enabler for them in terms
of their success you can see and here
the blue bar is the number of graduates

you can see that in some cases not many
have experienced significant or general
lining management experience but a lot
of them the majority of them that have
have actually found it to be extremely
beneficial I just want to talk about one
other final thing which is sort of the
impact of race on your career so one of
the things that we were interested in
asking was if you think about race is
that been an advantage a disadvantage or
neutral in terms of your career and we
asked this for black and white
respondents and you can see the
highlight here is that we asked them
about leaving HBS so anticipatory when
you were leaving HBS what was your
expectation and then reflecting back how
did you actually experience it so what
we see here is that black women expected
their race to be a disadvantage and they
experienced it as such black men did not
necessarily expect their race to be as
big of a disadvantage but they still
experience it to that particular level
so it's one of the things and we have
the same thing for gender in terms of
whether you expected that to be an
advantage or a disadvantage here so this
is in terms of gender did you expect
your gender to be an advantage a
disadvantage or neutral in your career
and actually we asked in our interviews
this was one of the questions that we
asked several of the women and so that
led to this final project and this is
the last slide I'll show you which is
part of the basis for the article which
you can read through our analysis we
ended up finding out that there were 532
african-american women who graduated
from HBS in the last 40 years and only
about 13% had reached the c-suite we
wanted to understand why is the number
so low and also to learn from those 13
percent so we went out and interviewed
we requested interview we interviewed
half of those women and the article
talks about what we learned from that
